(1) "dominating area bc get money from U.S" - your syllogistic conclusion 
does not follow from your premises. Proof: they get money and arms from U.S 
and PA gets little, therefore the conclusion is Isr. should not use arms 
against PA? Does not even come close to following a syllogistic sequence 
here. 
(2) missed "Occupation!!!" = Regression fallacy, proof = there was conflict 
before the occupation. Even if true - which it is not shown with preceding 
statement - suffers from Fallacy of single cause which 'occupation' surely 
is not even if true (which it is not). 
(3) occupation and science/education connection - your conclusion says if 
educated should not occupy - again your syllogistic conclusion does not 
follow from your premise. Proof: I am PhD and I can think of reasons for 
one country to occupy another. Or more proof, how about U.S occupying 
Hawaii (had its own kingdom). Britain was educated and occupied other 
nations. France. Portugal. China occupies Tibet (longest in world).
(4) "..But I guess not..." - suffers from argument from incredulity - where 
try to appeal to common sense as a legitimate reason for conclusion. More 
so, also your correlation proves causation argument is deeply flawed - 
"i.e. because educated less likely to occupy" - you would fail every single 
science course. You could say there is a correlation of those more 
"educated countries" (by what standards) occupying less countries than 
others, but you could never draw a causal argument from this. 
(5) how would Bill feel if his home was occupied - false equivalency or 
false analogy given the fact that the premise is really the conclusion- 
well why was his home occupied? If the premise is that he was planning an 
attack from his home you better believe his home should be occupied. He of 
course would not like it, but who cares, he is a security risk to others. 
(6) stupid Netanyahu argument - ad hominem and argumentum ad lapidem - 
dismissing claim as absurd without demonstrating proof

point

and the fact that they do not is evidence in support of Isr. institution 
intends to coexist.

false analogy. appeal to false motive. 
(11) Because jews feel persecuted then bomb for 12 days - so much wrong 
with this. You think that this is the reason for bombing for 12 days??? Not

kyle, you're trying to make this a black and white issue; it isnt. the fact 
of the matter is a nation will ALWAYS retaliate when attacked. israel is an 
aggressive expansionist force in the region yes, but they are also under 
constant terrorist threat on a daily basis. on the same token, the 
palestinians have been robbed of their land and been told to deal with it, 
while also supporting (oftentimes indirectly) terrorist actions against 
israel. at very least they allow these terrorist groups to continue to 
operate within their borders, forcing israel to police these cities for 
them, rather than the palestinians eradicating the forces of hamas 
themselves.

my point is, noone is good or bad, they're both good and bad. 

this is the unfortunate reality:

israel has a MASSIVE upper hand in this conflict, and if the Palestinian 
people were smart they would vehemently oppose hamas, as this group has 
forced Israel to do exactly what we all knew they would do - invade. it is 
in the best interest of both Israel and palestine to eradicate hamas and 
groups like it, because palestine has virtually zero power in this 
conflict. they have no allies willing to go to bat for them. they have no 
resources or military force to repel invaders. they are, unfortunately, in 
a position currently that requires capitulation, lest they lose even more 
of their land. and ill predict that they will if they allow groups like 
Hamas to continue to operate in their cities.

as much as i hate to say it (lest i sound like a republitard), this is the 
way of the world. the strong pick on the weak and take what they want. in 
this particular instance, i fear palestine is once again going to lose more 
land. This is unfortunate, but i do have to state the obvious: why should 
we feel sorry for such a pathetic society. now please dont bite my head 
off, i know how that sounds. But in a purely nationalistic sense, a society 
that has rejected science, education, advancement, modern technology, and 
opted to be an isolationist, hyper religious society does not warrant a 
whole lot of sympathy when now they cry for someone to defend them. they, 
as a society have chosen to be weak, and a more dominant society has the 
power to take what they want. again, in a purely nationalistic, macro view 
of societies, this is survival of the fittest. societies like the american 
Indians and the middle east have intentionally chosen to be weak, and now 
cry over being bullied by other nations.

Now, after all that said, i hate war and hate killing of non combatants, so 
i oppose this operation on those moral grounds. but again, i dont think 
that one can completely dismiss the fact that weak societies get conquered. 
this is the way things are, have been, and always will be. the key to peace 
is strength. when these societies opt to be weak, as calloused as it is to 
say, you cant feel that badly for them when they get bullied.﻿

Ya know, I'd fully agree with this if not for one small very annoying fact:

It isn't like Hamas just puts its military hardware out away from its 
civilian population zones, so it isn't like Israeli forces can just say "oh 
hey, evil death machine over here, innocent little children over there, 
let's go and destroy the evil death machine". If ONLY it were that easy. 
The Geneva Conventions generally try to deter people from putting military 
targets near civilian populations (which, by the way, become legal military 
targets if they're used for so much as being a weapons cache) for this 
exact reason--that 77% civilians statistic.

See, here's a little analogous experiment:

You have 100 marbles. 77 are blue, 23 are red.

You want to take a garden hose and splash water on the 23 red marbles, 
without getting a single blue marble wet.

First, put the 23 red marbles in one pile, and the 77 blue marbles in 
another. Odds are, it's going to be pretty damn easy to to get the red 
marbles all wet, and leave the blue ones dry.

Now put them all in one pile. You still must get every single one of those 
red marbles wet.

How many of those blue marbles will you soak as well?

Sucks, doesn't it?

This is why the Geneva Conventions try to deter people from creating combat 
zones out of civilian population centers. Hamas must have missed the memo. 
And you seem to have missed the memo that this is the situation on the 
ground.

If it were a case of "hey Israel, you have excellent intelligence telling 
you that the missile stocks and missile launchers are over there in the 
desert, and that all of this civilian infrastructure is only used for 
peaceful purposes", then you would be 110% correct, and that the Israeli 
army would be acting viciously.

But...well...that's just not what's happening on the ground.

Also, in regards to the whole "occupation" thing: Israel unilaterally 
withdrew from Gaza in 2005. There isn't a single Israeli stationed in Gaza. 
Blockade? Maybe. Occupation? No.﻿

between Gaza Strip and Israel. Due to a severe lack of job opportunities 
and a shortage of construction material entering Gaza from Israel, hundreds 
of men and boys scavenge for building gravel amongst the destroyed 
buildings close to the border fence. The gravel is collected into sacks, 
loaded onto donkey drawn carts and sold to builders for use in concrete. 
Children can earn up to 50 shekels (US $13) per day which is used to help 
support their families. Reports indicate that Israeli soldiers on duty in 
the observation towers which line the border between Gaza and Israel 
frequently fire warning shots to scare workers away from the border region. *Reports

children report being shot whilst working between 50 to 800 metres from the 
border fence.*

 Selena Gomez.
